author: DAVID EGGERT
title: Bill regulating amateur martial arts fights nears final OK
text:
Bill regulating amateur martial arts fights nears final OK By DAVID EGGERT   
LANSING, Mich. (AP) - A plan to regulate mixed martial arts bouts between amateur fighters neared Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder’s desk late Wednesday after lawmakers voted to rein in what one called an unsafe “Wild West” culture. 
The main bill, which won approval in the House on a 97-9 vote, would regulate amateur MMA contests like professional MMA fights and boxing. Licensing fees would be assessed on contestants, promoters, judges, referees and others. 
Athletes would compete in weight classes, fight lengths would be limited, drug testing would be required, a doctor and ambulance would be onsite, and promoters would have to submit a bond to the Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs before the agency could approve an event. 
“This is the Wild, Wild West of MMA. We’re one of I think a handful of states that just doesn’t have any regulations on amateur mixed martial arts,” said Rep. Harvey Santana, a Detroit Democrat. His bill, passed unanimously by the Senate, would make it a maximum three-year felony to knowingly allow a professional to compete in an MMA fight with an amateur. 
Amateur events, he said, are prevalent every weekend across the state and some promoters are “unscrupulous.” 
“They don’t care about the fighter. They just care that the fighter wants to jump in the cage,” Santana said. “They don’t care about the fighter’s record, how long they’ve been training, what their skill set is. They’ll put them in there with a very inexperienced fighter, and that can lead to a very big problem.” 
A second bill would prohibit a promoter from hosting a professional boxing match or any MMA bout without at least one inspector present. 
Both bills need final procedural approval, which could come Thursday, before they go to Snyder for his expected signature. Similar legislation was introduced in the last three two-year legislative sessions but failed to win passage.
